title: Illegal Hacker Crackdown
historical_context: This article reflects the increasing legal actions against hackers in the late 1980s, a time when computer-related crimes were becoming more prevalent and recognized by law enforcement.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in the history of computer crime.
short_summary: The article discusses the crackdown on illegal hacking activities in the U.S., highlighting significant cases and the financial impact of computer fraud on telecommunications companies.
summary: In this article, Al Simmons reports on the intensified efforts by authorities to combat illegal hacking, which has resulted in significant financial losses for long-distance communications companies. The piece details the first adult conviction for hacking in San Francisco, where Steve Cseh pled guilty to obtaining telephone services fraudulently. His case exemplifies the legal repercussions that hackers face, including probation and restitution to the victim company, U.S. Sprint. The article also mentions the extensive investigative work that led to Cseh's arrest, showcasing the collaboration between law enforcement and telecommunications security teams.
summary_extended: Simmons further elaborates on another case involving Thomas Gould Alvord, who was arrested for running an electronic theft ring that accrued over $2 million in unauthorized calls. Alvord's operation involved using automated dialing systems to exploit long-distance access codes, which he sold to various clients, including truck drivers and businesses. The article underscores the growing sophistication of hacking techniques and the corresponding legal responses, as authorities adapt to the evolving landscape of computer crime. This piece serves as a historical snapshot of the early days of computer hacking legislation, illustrating the challenges faced by law enforcement in addressing these emerging threats.
